Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warmup**

10 minutes @ RPE 2-4 -- 120-145% of RTP -- HR 70-87% (Z2)

​

**Activation**

2 x 100m accelerations with 1 minute recovery (jog) between

​

**Main effort**

Number of Sets: 3

Interval Distance: 1 mile

Interval Intensity: 10k pace (RPE 6.5-7 -- 100-110% of RTP -- HR 95-100%) (Z4a)

Recovery duration: 2-3 minutes between efforts @ RPE 2-4 -- 120-145% of RTP -- HR 70-87% (Z2)

When you can no longer keep the pace, the workout is over.

​

**Cool Down**

Finish with several 100-meter strides on grass

prospects.name: Endurance  1
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 2

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Full Frontal (4DP Assessment)
prospects.description:
Full Frontal: The Complete One.

We recommend the Full Frontal 4DP fitness assessment for:

- Experienced riders.
- Athletes with experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those about to start—or who have just finished—a training plan.

This is our full 4DP fitness test and is the only test that exposes every aspect of your unique physiology in a single hour. Developed by Head of Wahoo Sports Science Coach Neal Henderson, Full Frontal uses the same lab-verified testing protocol that Coach Neal has used at the highest level for over a decade with professional and amateur athletes.

​

This test will provide you with a complete Four-Dimensional Power profile, identify your Rider Type, and tell you exactly what aspects of your fitness you need to focus on to become a more complete cyclist. More importantly, SYSTM will then use your results to set personalized power targets for all of your workouts based on your unique profile, resulting in the most precise, effective workouts available. Your results will also be used to tailor all of your training plans.

​

We recommend re-testing with Full Frontal every 8-12 weeks or as prescribed by your training plan.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: The Other French Race
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Rupert Guinness entered the Haute Route Alps in France looking for a new challenge to test his physical and mental strength. But after 800km of cycling through the Alps from Nice to Megève, the cycling journalist and author realized that the experience had delivered to him and the 400-plus starters something far greater. It had provided them with the adventure of a lifetime; from a sense of what it would be like to ride in the fabled Tour de France that he has reported on more than 30 times, to the creation of friendships with fellow riders forged by their shared suffering and encouragement for one another as they cycled through some of the toughest and most spectacular mountains that cycling has to offer.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Recovery Run
prospects.description:
This is as easy as easy gets.

You should hardly be going fast enough to consider this a jog.

You want to focus on taking very short strides but keeping your stride rate at least 80 steps per minute.

You should be embarrassed to be seen going this slowly!

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

prospects.name: 5K Pace Test
prospects.description:
For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 145% of RTP -- HR <70% (Z1)

5 minute build from RPE 2 to RPE 4 -- 145-120% of RTP -- HR 70-87% (Z2)

​

**Activation 1: Accelerations**

Number of Sets 2

Rest Between Sets 60-90 seconds

Interval Effort: 90sec Accelerations from RPE 4 up to RPE 7 (Z2-Z4b)

Recovery: 90 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 145% of RTP -- HR <70% (Z1)

**Activation 2: Strides**

Number of Sets 4-6

Rest Between Sets: 1 min

Interval Distance: 80m build

Interval Effort: Gradual increase @ RPE 3-8 (Z2 building to Z4)

Recovery: 30+ seconds @ RPE <2 -->145% of RTP -- HR <70% (Z1)

​

**Main Effort**

5K Test If you aren’t sure what pace you can sustain keep the RPE around 7 for the first 1500m, then build from that pace or keep it steady. Take note of your 1K splits to see if you are fading or building by the end. Record your time for the full 5k and average heart rate for the last 20 minutes. To calculate your running Lactate Threshold Heart Rate (LTHR), subtract 10bpm from the average HR of your last 20 minutes and add 15sec to your average kilometer splits to determine Running Threshold Pace (RTP).

​

**Cool Down**

5-10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 145% of RTP -- HR <70% (Z1)

​

prospects.name: 03. Establishing the Goal Setting Habit
prospects.description:
**GOAL SETTING**

A clear plan of action is essential to any undertaking. Setting concrete, actionable goals will keep you motivated and on track; whether you’re eyeing the top podium step or the summit of the local climb. We will help assess where you are today, where you want to go, and identify the steps needed to get there.

​

In this module, you will enable consistent progress by creating a habit of identifying monthly and weekly goals, with weekly rewards for achieving those goals.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

​

​

​

​

prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Hamstrings and TFL for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session is designed to strengthen and stretch the back of your thighs and outside hips to improve mobility and ensure proper function. It can help to alleviate lower back pain and can be practiced in the morning, evening, or directly after training.

Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners I
prospects.description: This flow sequence focuses on improving mobility in the hips. It’s the perfect active recovery routine to practice on your day off, energize you first thing in the morning, or flow-through before your run. To get the most out of this session, try to synchronize your breathing and movement while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Supple Spine & Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back. As you become familiar with the routine, you can begin to focus on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to use nasal breathing as much as possible. It is an excellent practice for the morning to warm up and improve focus, or it can be done directly after a workout to help prevent extreme muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Downward Dog
- Crescent Lunge
- Bridge
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Balance and Core Control for Runners
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve your balance and core control, indispensable skills for all runners. We strengthen the abs, obliques, and hips, with a focus on moving slowly with control, dynamically between the postures.

prospects.name: Post-Run Stretch
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to keep you strong, supple, and always in the game. It’s a simple and easy series of poses that slowly and carefully allows you to release tension in the primary muscles of the lower body, including the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, glutes, piriformis, and lower back.

prospects.name: Mobilize Your Body
prospects.description:
In this video, we focus on mobilizing the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, ankles, and toes to enhance overall mobility throughout the body. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or evening to alleviate stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase mobility in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, and ankles.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Screaming Toe
- Wrist Circles
- Elbow Circles
- Shoulder Circles
- Neck Circles
- Thunderbolt
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Thoracic Spine Circles
- Seated Twists
- Hip Circles
- Squat Twists
- Standing Forward Bends
- Reclining Hip Circles
- Windscreen Wipers
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Foot and Ankle Mobility for Runners
prospects.description: In this restorative sequence, we mobilize the toes, feet, and ankles; stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips. We start with a simple foot massage to bring movement into every part of your foot, from your toes up to your heel. With this extra range of motion, we then move into some gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips.

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Breathing More Deeply
prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Stretch Out Your Legs
prospects.description:
This cool-down stretch is designed to release tension in the legs and hips, targeting the glutes, piriformis, calves, hamstrings, groin, quads, TFL, and lower back. It's an ideal routine for athletes to practice directly after a workout or in the evening before bed.

​

The objectives include stretching the glutes, piriformis, hamstrings, calves, groin, quads, and TFL, releasing tension in the lower back, and helping the body transition into the parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, potentially alleviating lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Reclining Groin Stretch
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Twist (Eagle Variation)

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Breathing to Calm Down I
prospects.description: 3-Part Breath is a therapeutic breathing technique that encourages you to use your full lung capacity. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Spinal Flexibility
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence focuses on enhancing spinal flexibility by moving the spine through flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral flexion. It targets the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes. This routine is excellent for increasing range of motion and reducing stiffness throughout the body. It can be practiced in the morning to help wake up or directly after a workout to prevent pain and stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase spine and shoulder mobility, stretch the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes, and reduce overall stiffness.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Sun Salutation
- Standing Sidebends
- Cat–Cow
- One-Handed Tiger
- Puppy + Twisted Puppy
- Seated Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Hips and Hamstrings
prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Breathing to Calm Down II
prospects.description: In 4-7-8 Breath your exhalations are twice as long as your inhalations. It's a therapeutic breathing technique that can help to reduce discomfort and calm your nervous system, especially when you're under pressure.

prospects.name: Hamstring & Hip Release
prospects.description:
This hip-opening sequence is particularly effective for stretching the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads. It's ideal for practicing after a workout or in the evening to increase flexibility and loosen up the hips.

​

The objectives are to stretch the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads; open up the hips; and trigger a parasympathetic nervous system response.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Child’s Pose
- Downward Dog
- Runners Lunge
- Side Lunge
- Lizard
- Frog
- Hip Circles
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe 1 + 2
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Lower Back Release
prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Wind-Relieving
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Dead Pigeon
- Happy Baby

prospects.name: Guided Meditation
prospects.description: This is a short guided meditation that focuses on your breath and the sensations in your body. Clearing your mind through meditation can help you increase your focus, which is an important skill when you're riding on the limit.

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Chest Opener
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to open up the chest and improve mobility in the spine and shoulders. It includes stretches for the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, hamstrings, and calves. The poses are particularly effective for alleviating pain between the shoulder blades. This sequence is ideal as a post-workout routine, especially after working the chest or engaging in activities that involve a closed-chest posture. It is also beneficial after a day spent hunched over a computer.

​

The objectives are to open up the chest, enhance mobility in the spine and shoulders, stretch the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, calves, and hamstrings, and help alleviate pain between the shoulders.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Cat–Cow with Forearm Stretch
- Puppy
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Downward Dog
- Low Lunge with Chest Opener
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Camel
- Wide-Knee Child’s Pose
- Reclining Butterfly (on blocks)

prospects.name: Balance Training for Runners
prospects.description: Balance training is crucial to improve your running performance, and yoga is a fantastic way to hone your skills. In this sequence, we practice a number of one-legged standing, dynamic poses to improve your balance and proprioception (your sense of where your body is in space). These poses are also great for building strength and flexibility in the hips.

prospects.name: Core Stability II for Runners
prospects.description: This simple core strength sequence has all your bases covered. We strengthen the deep core stabilizers, superficial abs, obliques, and lower back. It’s a great one to do before your run to activate key muscle groups, in the morning to set you up for the day, or after an easy run.

prospects.name: Body Scan
prospects.description:
This body scan meditation is designed to transition the body from the sympathetic to the parasympathetic nervous system response. It can be practiced directly after a workout as a cool-down or before bed to facilitate deep, restorative sleep.

​

The objectives are to calm the central nervous system, transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, improve focus, and relieve stress.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.

prospects.name: Core Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the spine, ribs and pelvis; strengthen the deep abdominals, obliques and lower back; and activate the glutes to improve balance, help to prevent and alleviate lower back pain and enhance athletic performance. It's a great session to do in the morning or pre-workout.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Foot and Ankle Mobility for Runners
prospects.description: In this restorative sequence, we mobilize the toes, feet, and ankles; stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips. We start with a simple foot massage to bring movement into every part of your foot, from your toes up to your heel. With this extra range of motion, we then move into some gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips.

prospects.name: Hamstrings and TFL for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session is designed to strengthen and stretch the back of your thighs and outside hips to improve mobility and ensure proper function. It can help to alleviate lower back pain and can be practiced in the morning, evening, or directly after training.

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Mobilize and Activate
prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Post-Run Stretch
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to keep you strong, supple, and always in the game. It’s a simple and easy series of poses that slowly and carefully allows you to release tension in the primary muscles of the lower body, including the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, glutes, piriformis, and lower back.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Pre-Ride Warm-Up
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to activate your posterior chain—the calves, hamstrings, glutes, lower, upper, and mid-back, as well as your core—the abs and obliques. It’s crucial that you engage these muscles before every ride to give you maximum power, speed, and endurance on the bike.

​

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Total Leg Strength
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to strengthen the legs, including the glutes, quads, hamstrings, calves, shins, ankles, and feet, while also improving mobility in the hips, spine, and shoulders. It provides a good stretch for the quads, hamstrings, and calves, making it ideal for activating the leg muscles in the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the glutes, quads, hamstrings, calves, shins, ankles, and feet; stretch the quads, hamstrings, and calves; and improve hip, spine, and shoulder mobility.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Chair + Chair Twist
- Runners Lunge
- High Lunge
- Silver Surfer
- Downward Dog
- Half-Reclining Hero
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Side Bends
prospects.description: If you're pushing yourself hard, it's likely you're getting stiff and sore all over. Side bends are one of my favorite ways to deal with general soreness. They're also perfect for cyclists who typically suffer from poor lateral flexibility.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners I
prospects.description: This flow sequence focuses on improving mobility in the hips. It’s the perfect active recovery routine to practice on your day off, energize you first thing in the morning, or flow-through before your run. To get the most out of this session, try to synchronize your breathing and movement while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Hip and Pelvis Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we strengthen the hips through their full range of motion and stabilize the pelvis to improve balance and reduce your risk of knee, IT band, and lower back injury. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Classic Yoga Flow
prospects.description:
This classic, hip-focused sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and strengthening the quads and hips. As you become familiar with the routine, you can work on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to breathe in and out through your nose throughout. It is an excellent practice for the morning to sharpen your focus or directly after a workout to help prevent muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, strengthen the hips and quads, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and groin, and practice synchronizing breath and movement.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- High Lunge (+ Twist)
- Downward Dog
- Warrior 2
- Triangle
- Squat
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Stretch Out Your Legs
prospects.description:
This cool-down stretch is designed to release tension in the legs and hips, targeting the glutes, piriformis, calves, hamstrings, groin, quads, TFL, and lower back. It's an ideal routine for athletes to practice directly after a workout or in the evening before bed.

​

The objectives include stretching the glutes, piriformis, hamstrings, calves, groin, quads, and TFL, releasing tension in the lower back, and helping the body transition into the parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, potentially alleviating lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Reclining Groin Stretch
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Twist (Eagle Variation)

prospects.name: One Hour Total Body Stretch
prospects.description:
This one-hour total body stretch includes 25 poses, starting with the upper body to stretch the neck, shoulders, chest, and forearms, then progressing to the lower back, glutes, groin, hip flexors, quads, hamstrings, calves, and ankles. It is an excellent routine to practice before bed to release tension in partially-contracted muscles and correct alignment. Deep relaxation into each pose, combined with nasal breathing and extended exhalations, enhances the stretch's intensity.

​

The objectives are to deeply relax the body and mind, loosen the neck and shoulders, increase spinal mobility, open up the hips (including the hip flexors, groin, glutes, and piriformis), stretch the calves and hamstrings, improve the range of motion in the feet and ankles, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

​

**Poses:**

- Thunderbolt
- Puppy + Reverse Prayer
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Half Monkey
- Side Lunge
- Half-Twisted Lizard
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Child
- Bridge
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe A + B
- Groin Stretch
- Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Eagle Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Butterfly

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Balance Training for Runners
prospects.description: Balance training is crucial to improve your running performance, and yoga is a fantastic way to hone your skills. In this sequence, we practice a number of one-legged standing, dynamic poses to improve your balance and proprioception (your sense of where your body is in space). These poses are also great for building strength and flexibility in the hips.

prospects.name: Hips and Hamstrings
prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Upper Body Strength
prospects.description: Those things you use to type and lift up your coffee cup? Yeah, those could be a bit stronger. So it's time to build strength in your upper body—in the hands, wrists, arms, shoulders, chest, and core. It is based around Sun Salutation, a yoga sequence that builds strength, increases power, and improves endurance.

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: Total Hip Therapy for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session stretches the hip muscles in all directions to ease pain and stiffness in the pelvis and lower back.  It’s a great one to practice after your run or before bed to ensure that you wake up feeling supple and pain-free.

prospects.name: Chest Opener
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to open up the chest and improve mobility in the spine and shoulders. It includes stretches for the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, hamstrings, and calves. The poses are particularly effective for alleviating pain between the shoulder blades. This sequence is ideal as a post-workout routine, especially after working the chest or engaging in activities that involve a closed-chest posture. It is also beneficial after a day spent hunched over a computer.

​

The objectives are to open up the chest, enhance mobility in the spine and shoulders, stretch the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, calves, and hamstrings, and help alleviate pain between the shoulders.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Cat–Cow with Forearm Stretch
- Puppy
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Downward Dog
- Low Lunge with Chest Opener
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Camel
- Wide-Knee Child’s Pose
- Reclining Butterfly (on blocks)

prospects.name: Balance & Mobility
prospects.description:
This balance sequence is excellent for training balance and proprioception, while also improving overall mobility, particularly in the spine and hips. It provides a challenging workout for the quads and glutes, making it a great choice for the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives include improving balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthening the knees, quads, and glutes; opening up the hips and chest; enhancing mobility in the spine; boosting focus and concentration; and practicing diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- High Lunge with Chest Opener
- Flying Lunge
- Warrior 3 with Chest Opener
- Chair Pose Twists
- Revolved Side Angle
- Awkward Pose
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Spinal Flexibility
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence focuses on enhancing spinal flexibility by moving the spine through flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral flexion. It targets the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes. This routine is excellent for increasing range of motion and reducing stiffness throughout the body. It can be practiced in the morning to help wake up or directly after a workout to prevent pain and stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase spine and shoulder mobility, stretch the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes, and reduce overall stiffness.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Sun Salutation
- Standing Sidebends
- Cat–Cow
- One-Handed Tiger
- Puppy + Twisted Puppy
- Seated Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners II
prospects.description: Building on the gains you've achieved after doing the Core Strengtheners exercises several times, this session further strengthens the core.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners II
prospects.description: In this flow sequence, we activate the muscles in both the upper and lower leg, move into stretches for the hip flexors and groin and finish with a deep hamstring stretch. You can practice this sequence in the morning, before your run, or on your day off as active recovery.

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Abs & Obliques
prospects.description:
This challenging core stability workout is designed to strengthen the abs, obliques, and lower back. It engages all three planes of motion—sagittal (planks), frontal (side planks), and transverse (poses with rotation)—to achieve maximum core strength and stability. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or as a standalone session.

​

The primary objective is to strengthen the core, including the abs, obliques, and lower back.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Plank
- Locust
- Spider Planks
- Child’s Pose
- Side Plank Variations
- Boat Variations
- Leg Raises
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Hamstring & Hip Release
prospects.description:
This hip-opening sequence is particularly effective for stretching the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads. It's ideal for practicing after a workout or in the evening to increase flexibility and loosen up the hips.

​

The objectives are to stretch the calves, hamstrings, groin, hip flexors, and quads; open up the hips; and trigger a parasympathetic nervous system response.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Child’s Pose
- Downward Dog
- Runners Lunge
- Side Lunge
- Lizard
- Frog
- Hip Circles
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe 1 + 2
- Knees-To-Chest

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners I
prospects.description: This flow sequence focuses on improving mobility in the hips. It’s the perfect active recovery routine to practice on your day off, energize you first thing in the morning, or flow-through before your run. To get the most out of this session, try to synchronize your breathing and movement while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Balance and Agility
prospects.description: Maintaining effective cycling form when you're under pressure requires substantial balance, coordination, agility, and core strength. This series will develop those capabilities so you can put down the power when it really matters.

prospects.name: Mobilize and Activate
prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Total Hip Therapy for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session stretches the hip muscles in all directions to ease pain and stiffness in the pelvis and lower back.  It’s a great one to practice after your run or before bed to ensure that you wake up feeling supple and pain-free.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Hamstring and Calf Flexibility
prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Pre-Ride Warm-Up
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to activate your posterior chain—the calves, hamstrings, glutes, lower, upper, and mid-back, as well as your core—the abs and obliques. It’s crucial that you engage these muscles before every ride to give you maximum power, speed, and endurance on the bike.

​

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Total Leg Strength
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to strengthen the legs, including the glutes, quads, hamstrings, calves, shins, ankles, and feet, while also improving mobility in the hips, spine, and shoulders. It provides a good stretch for the quads, hamstrings, and calves, making it ideal for activating the leg muscles in the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the glutes, quads, hamstrings, calves, shins, ankles, and feet; stretch the quads, hamstrings, and calves; and improve hip, spine, and shoulder mobility.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Chair + Chair Twist
- Runners Lunge
- High Lunge
- Silver Surfer
- Downward Dog
- Half-Reclining Hero
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hamstrings and TFL for Runners
prospects.description: This therapeutic session is designed to strengthen and stretch the back of your thighs and outside hips to improve mobility and ensure proper function. It can help to alleviate lower back pain and can be practiced in the morning, evening, or directly after training.

prospects.name: Side Bends
prospects.description: If you're pushing yourself hard, it's likely you're getting stiff and sore all over. Side bends are one of my favorite ways to deal with general soreness. They're also perfect for cyclists who typically suffer from poor lateral flexibility.

prospects.name: Off Balance
prospects.description:
This balance sequence starts with engaging one-legged standing postures that strengthen the feet, ankles, hips, and glutes, and concludes with a challenging Side Plank series aimed at strengthening the hips, abs, and obliques. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives are to improve balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthen the feet, ankles, hips, glutes, core, arms, and shoulders; enhance focus and concentration; and practice diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Tiptoes
- Sidebending-Tree
- Knee Hugs
- Dancer
- Side Plank Variations
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hip and Pelvis Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we strengthen the hips through their full range of motion and stabilize the pelvis to improve balance and reduce your risk of knee, IT band, and lower back injury. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Hip Mobility Flow for Runners II
prospects.description: In this flow sequence, we activate the muscles in both the upper and lower leg, move into stretches for the hip flexors and groin and finish with a deep hamstring stretch. You can practice this sequence in the morning, before your run, or on your day off as active recovery.

prospects.name: One Hour Total Body Stretch
prospects.description:
This one-hour total body stretch includes 25 poses, starting with the upper body to stretch the neck, shoulders, chest, and forearms, then progressing to the lower back, glutes, groin, hip flexors, quads, hamstrings, calves, and ankles. It is an excellent routine to practice before bed to release tension in partially-contracted muscles and correct alignment. Deep relaxation into each pose, combined with nasal breathing and extended exhalations, enhances the stretch's intensity.

​

The objectives are to deeply relax the body and mind, loosen the neck and shoulders, increase spinal mobility, open up the hips (including the hip flexors, groin, glutes, and piriformis), stretch the calves and hamstrings, improve the range of motion in the feet and ankles, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

​

**Poses:**

- Thunderbolt
- Puppy + Reverse Prayer
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Half Monkey
- Side Lunge
- Half-Twisted Lizard
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Child
- Bridge
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe A + B
- Groin Stretch
- Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Eagle Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Butterfly

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Post-Run Stretch
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to keep you strong, supple, and always in the game. It’s a simple and easy series of poses that slowly and carefully allows you to release tension in the primary muscles of the lower body, including the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, glutes, piriformis, and lower back.

prospects.name: Hips and Hamstrings
prospects.description: This routine is designed to open up the hips—the hip flexors, rotators, and glutes—and stretch the hamstrings. The session guides you through a series of lunges and finishes with Lizard and Pigeon pose. You can practice it in the morning, before or after a ride. Experiment to see what works best for you.

prospects.name: Peak Pose Wheel
prospects.description:
This sequence builds towards the advanced backbend, Wheel pose. To prepare for this pose, the routine focuses on mobilizing the spine and shoulders and opening up the fronts of the hips. It is best practiced when fully warmed up, with careful attention to the lower back and only moving within safe ranges of motion. For those who can practice Wheel safely, it serves as an excellent counterpose to common postures from cycling or sitting at a desk, potentially alleviating lower back, upper back, and shoulder pain. For those not yet ready for Wheel, the other poses in this sequence are also effective for addressing muscular imbalances.

​

The objectives are to increase spinal and shoulder mobility, stretch the abs, chest, and fronts of the shoulders, open up the hip flexors, activate the glutes, and help alleviate lower and upper back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Supported Bridge
- Thunderbolt—Shoulder Rolls
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Puppy
- Downward Facing Dog
- Cobra
- Low Lunge with Shoulder Opener
- Bridge
- Wheel
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Balance & Mobility
prospects.description:
This balance sequence is excellent for training balance and proprioception, while also improving overall mobility, particularly in the spine and hips. It provides a challenging workout for the quads and glutes, making it a great choice for the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives include improving balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthening the knees, quads, and glutes; opening up the hips and chest; enhancing mobility in the spine; boosting focus and concentration; and practicing diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- High Lunge with Chest Opener
- Flying Lunge
- Warrior 3 with Chest Opener
- Chair Pose Twists
- Revolved Side Angle
- Awkward Pose
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Chest Opener
prospects.description:
This sequence is designed to open up the chest and improve mobility in the spine and shoulders. It includes stretches for the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, hamstrings, and calves. The poses are particularly effective for alleviating pain between the shoulder blades. This sequence is ideal as a post-workout routine, especially after working the chest or engaging in activities that involve a closed-chest posture. It is also beneficial after a day spent hunched over a computer.

​

The objectives are to open up the chest, enhance mobility in the spine and shoulders, stretch the forearms, shoulders, chest, hip flexors, calves, and hamstrings, and help alleviate pain between the shoulders.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Cat–Cow with Forearm Stretch
- Puppy
- Half-Twisted Scorpion
- Downward Dog
- Low Lunge with Chest Opener
- Kneeling Cat-Cow
- Camel
- Wide-Knee Child’s Pose
- Reclining Butterfly (on blocks)

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Spinal Flexibility
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence focuses on enhancing spinal flexibility by moving the spine through flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral flexion. It targets the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes. This routine is excellent for increasing range of motion and reducing stiffness throughout the body. It can be practiced in the morning to help wake up or directly after a workout to prevent pain and stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase spine and shoulder mobility, stretch the shoulders, lats, obliques, lower back, quads, and glutes, and reduce overall stiffness.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Sun Salutation
- Standing Sidebends
- Cat–Cow
- One-Handed Tiger
- Puppy + Twisted Puppy
- Seated Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Hip Openers
prospects.description: Seeing gains from the _Hip Openers_ session? This series will build on those gains, further loosening overworked and inflexible muscles in and around the hip joints.

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners II
prospects.description: Building on the gains you've achieved after doing the Core Strengtheners exercises several times, this session further strengthens the core.

prospects.name: Post-Run Cool-Down
prospects.description:
This video is designed for practice directly after a run, but the long-hold poses are also effective after any lower body workout.

​

The routine focuses on stretching major hip muscles, including the hip flexors, groin, and glutes, as well as the feet, ankles, calves, hamstrings, and quads. The objectives include stretching the feet, ankles, calves, and hamstrings, releasing tension in the quads, hip flexors, glutes, and groin, and potentially alleviating lower back pain. Additionally, it helps transition the body into the parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode following a run or workout.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Screaming Toe
- Downward Dog
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Quad Stretch
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe 1 + 2

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Abs & Obliques
prospects.description:
This challenging core stability workout is designed to strengthen the abs, obliques, and lower back. It engages all three planes of motion—sagittal (planks), frontal (side planks), and transverse (poses with rotation)—to achieve maximum core strength and stability. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or as a standalone session.

​

The primary objective is to strengthen the core, including the abs, obliques, and lower back.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Plank
- Locust
- Spider Planks
- Child’s Pose
- Side Plank Variations
- Boat Variations
- Leg Raises
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Stretch Out Your Legs
prospects.description:
This cool-down stretch is designed to release tension in the legs and hips, targeting the glutes, piriformis, calves, hamstrings, groin, quads, TFL, and lower back. It's an ideal routine for athletes to practice directly after a workout or in the evening before bed.

​

The objectives include stretching the glutes, piriformis, hamstrings, calves, groin, quads, and TFL, releasing tension in the lower back, and helping the body transition into the parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise, potentially alleviating lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Reclining Groin Stretch
- Reclining Quad Stretch
- Reclining Spinal Twist (Eagle Variation)

prospects.name: Foot and Ankle Mobility for Runners
prospects.description: In this restorative sequence, we mobilize the toes, feet, and ankles; stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips. We start with a simple foot massage to bring movement into every part of your foot, from your toes up to your heel. With this extra range of motion, we then move into some gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips.

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.
